kubernetes clusters so they might have
multiple applications they might have

kubernetes cluster the answer is reduced

but we think that there is absolutely a

but
still think that there is a need for

one of the things that people say if you
are in the multi-tenancy group and
you'll hear this a lot is nobody agrees
on what a tenant is so I mostly put this
light up to show you that we do agree on
what a tenant is so we have we have an
entire really awesome dock that Eastway
who at Google has put together called
the tenant concept in kubernetes but at
a high level what we're saying is a
tenant represents a group of kubernetes
users a tenant has certain accessibility
to a group of resources in a kubernetes
cluster a tenant can manage
accessibility of the group of resources
for subgroups of users limited by the
accessibility granted to the tenant a
tenant can be allocated quota to consume
resources in a kubernetes cluster a
kubernetes cluster is shared by one or
more tenants who are either isolated or
not isolated and in a kubernetes cluster
a tenant is an entity representing a
group of resources with defined
accessibility in quota so you can see
what we're doing here is we're really
trying to define what is that use case
why do people need multi-tenancy and
then how do we draw a circle around what
multi-tenancy is without making it too
restrictive in a way that really cuts
out a lot of important use cases for
people but also with having a clear
enough definition that this really gives
us a problem that we as a group and a
community can tackle so this tenancy
calm concept in kubernetes dock is open
for comment it was presented two weeks
ago to the community and to ago before
that and we're continuing to gather
feedback and really iterate on that
so different tenancy models you'll hear
these terms a lot when you engage with
the multi-tenancy working group so I
just kind of wanted to get everyone on
the same page about what we're talking
about so we have soft multi-tenancy and
we have hard multi-tenancy and really
what we're talking about is how isolated
we can make the tenants within your
kubernetes cluster so today we can
achieve soft multi-tenancy in kubernetes
there are some gaps there's some feature
gaps and there's also there is not an
official kubernetes profile that says if
you run this exact profile then you will
get a soft multi tenant kubernetes
cluster and it's signed off by
kubernetes and we all agree this is a
soft multi-tenancy cluster that's all
work that this working group wants to
address but what soft multi-tenancy
means is it's a model of multi-tenancy
in which the users of the shared cluster
are somewhat trusted so you're not
saying that I'm going to run something
that complete strangers are kind of come
in and try to escape everything there is
some contract between the runner of the
cluster and the users of the cluster
that says I you know maybe I'm an
employee like I have a vested interest
in not messing with you too much and if
I do mess with you it's going to be
logged and I'm gonna get fired so we
have this idea that people have an
incentive to act as a good actor on the
system so tenants don't have access to
anything from other tenants but it would
be accessible for example to share the
API we don't need a completely dedicated
and isolated API or control plane per
user now hard multi-tenancy is going one
step further or many steps further and
saying that this is a model of
multi-tenancy in which there is zero
trust between users of a shared cluster
to behave as good actors on the system
and so a tenant shouldn't have any
access to anything from other tenants
except from and so this is actually a
major point of debate so here we're
saying except for the kubernetes api
which could be protected but still
accessible to allow tenants users to run
their own controllers and operators and
take other actions on other objects
between their namespaces but there are
some people who say that there actually
can be zero trust and zero sharing of
that API control plane so that's
something that we need to have models
for both
likely and there has been a really great
series of presentations the first of
which was two weeks ago at the

how one company Alibaba has been

they are gathering feedback in use cases
because they want to make this a project
that's very useful for a lot of people
